jobs.delivery_pubname: p: Tufts E-News, p: You Make It Happen
jobs.delivery_special:
These will go with a story on Sykes and his grad students who are working with high school students trying to get them to gain an interest in science. I would like photos with Sykes and his grad students, particularly Erin Iski and April Jewell, who will be quoted in the piece. Georgy was also hoping we could have Roger Winn in the photographs, he is the teacher of the high school students who also happens to be a Tufts grad. I will be contact him in the next day or so, so I will try and see what his availability is. I am going to put a two week window on this, but if they happen to be done before than that would be great as well. Here is a rundown Suzanne came gave us to give you a better idea of the project.
---------------------------------------------------- Tufts University Assistant Professor Charles Sykes has noticed two unfortunate trends in his field of physical chemistry: a lack of diversity and a lack of newcomers entering the field. It seemed to him that by fixing the first problem, the second might resolve itself.
His plan involves iPods -- but not simply recording lectures and sharing other information through podcasts (although his lab has recorded popular demonstrational YouTube videos). Instead, Sykes is using iPods and a nifty device called a scanning tunneling microscope (STM) to get high school and college students interested in nanoscience (the study of things that are one billionth of a meter in size or 80,000 times thinner than a human hair).
Unlike conventional microscopes, the STM does not rely on using visible light to image the sample. Because its resolution is not limited by the wavelength of light, STM technology produces much higher resolution images. Expensive research STMs have been used to investigate and manipulate single atoms and molecules. Now a new breed of inexpensive, portable STMs is making it possible to bring STM technology into the classroom, providing highly visual and hands-on ways for students to learn the abstract concepts of nanoscience and quantum mechanics.
"High school kids love talking about their iPods and the devices are an example of nano-scale electronics," says Sykes.
On April 15, two doctoral students from Sykes 'chemistry lab at Tufts, Erin Iski and April Jewell, gave several presentations to Roger Winn's chemistry classes at the Social Justice Academy in Boston. They brought their portable STM to give students an opportunity to see graphite atoms in their pencils at the nanoscale.
In addition, they used the iPod as an example for their research because they learned during a presentation last year that students understand that you can store 3,000 songs on an iPod. Iski and Jewell showed the students the size of current iPod electrical circuits. They explained to the students that for researchers to shrink down those circuits -- what the Sykes lab is doing with other materials -- means the storage space on an iPod could go from 3,000 songs to 3 million songs.
This example they usually clearly understand.
On April 22, 10 students from Winn's class will visit Tufts to see more of what is involved in studying chemistry in college from visiting the lab, conducting experiments using the STM, eating lunch in the dining hall and attending a chemistry lecture.
After being awarded a 2009 Career Award from the National Science Foundation, Sykes hopes to not only continue his cutting edge surface chemistry research, but also to carry on the educational components with high school students as well as their teachers through summer training, and to introduce STM experiments into college curriculum.
------------- ADVANCEMENT COMMUNICATIONS:
Please connect with Mike Sherman to discuss a location for a shoot that includes Professor Sykes, who has been recognized by the NSF with one of their prestigious CAREER awards. CAREERS, formally called The Faculty Early Career Development Program, offers the National Science Foundation's most prestigious awards in support of junior faculty who exemplify the role of teacher-scholars through outstanding research, excellent education, and the integration of education and research within their organizations. Professor Sykes' award has been granted for "Investigating and Controlling Molecular Rotation on Surfaces." He will be featured in a publication we produce on gift impact to donors who supported Tufts in FY09. We understand that this is a very busy time and are happy to use a freelancer for this project if that is helpful. Thanks!

jobs.delivery_special:
Construction is under way at Cousens Gym to rotate the basketball court (basically turning it in the opposite direction) to meet NCAA regulations so championship games can be played at Tufts. Cousens Gym was constructed in 1931 during the height of the Great Depression. Now, during the height of the Great Recession, Tufts is doing work on the gym again.
This photo will basically recreate, 78 years later, the shot of then Tufts President John Albert Cousens driving the steam shovel (see attached archival shots) when ground was broken for the gym. Only this time, it will be Larry Bacow operating the heavy equipment.
The shoot will take place sometime between 12:30 and 3 p.m. on Monday, May 4 (I'll confirm the time as soon as I get it).
Make photos available on Merlin.
To be shot same day as Varis Auditorium job.

jobs.shoot_address: 14 Whittier St. Cambridge ner Porter Sq.
jobs.delivery_special:
The story Helene is working on centers on Ackerman's new book, Can We Afford the Future? It would be nice to do something other than the usual office shot. He's an environmentally correct person, riding his bike to work, etc. Maybe there's something there to work with...
From Amazon about the book:
According to many scientists, climate change is a growing threat to life as we know it, requiring a large-scale, immediate response. According to many economists, climate change is a moderately important problem; the best policy is a slow, gradual start, to avoid spending too much. They can't both be right.
In this book, Frank Ackerman offers a refreshing look at the economics of climate change, explaining how the arbitrary assumptions of conventional theories get in the way of understanding this urgent problem. The benefits of climate protection are vital but priceless, and hence often devalued in cost-benefit calculations. Preparation for the most predictable outcomes of global warming is less important than protection against the growing risk of catastrophic change; massive investment in new, low carbon technologies and industries should be thought of as life insurance for the planet.
Ackerman makes an impassioned plea to construct a better economics, arguing that the solutions are affordable and the alternative is unthinkable. If we can't afford the future, what are we saving our money for?

jobs.delivery_pubname: e: International Class Clinical Advancement Ceremony
jobs.delivery_special:
Candids, group shots and podium shots
Hi Katy, Joanie, and Alonso,
I'm thrilled to hear that one of you will be available to come out to shoot the International Clinical Advancement Ceremony next Wednesday. The Clinical Advancement Ceremony, also known as the White Coat Ceremony, is fairly small-scale in comparison to the larger DMD Class Advancement Ceremony which takes place every March and usually has over 600 people in attendance. There are just 17 international students in this year's class and there will be approximately 85 faculty, staff, and family members in attendance this year. The ceremony is set to start at noon and will likely last about 45 minutes. Mark Gonthier, Dean Norris and possibly EAD Dean Joe Castellana will speak, Dr. Robert Doherty and Dr. Iqbal Singh will also play a role in the ceremony. The ceremony will take place in the 7th floor student lounge. There will be a podium and chairs set up. It would be great to get some candids of the speakers, and the international class (who will be seated in the first few rows). Also, each student will be called up to receive their white coat and we would like to get a couple of shots of each student with the Deans.
After the ceremony, we would like to get a group shot of the international class and the deans. There will be a Tufts Dental banner hanging in the Becker Board Room and we would like to set the group shot up in front of that banner.
Lastly, there will be a luncheon following the ceremony. It would be great to get a bunch of candids of the students and their family members and the various faculty.
Let me know if you have any questions or need any additional information.
Thanks, Carrie
jobs.internal_notes: 8/24: delivered via photoshelter. -jt

jobs.delivery_special:
Dennett's lower-level intro to philo class, for story on E-News about how fresh/soph can get exposure to world-class luminary professor.
Robinson 253 is a boring, large normally lit lecture hall. Class has ~100 people. Would ideally like to show engagement of students with Dennett -- maybe would be best to come at end of class to get shots during class and of students (possibly) coming up afterwards to ask questions? We can talk about it.
Class has active dialogue, lots of raised hands.
Dennett requests brief, discreet, inobstrusive shoot. You may want to ask him his definition of brief. (Daniel.Dennett@tufts.edu)
Class is held 1:30 to ~2:45. Description on website says 2:20 but when Suzanne and I went, it was longer.
Class description: http://ase.tufts.edu/philosophy/courses/descriptions.asp#003

Penn

jobs.delivery_special:
This so for a story on the new "natural playground" that was recently installed behind the Eliot-Pearson school. We'd like to get a few shots with kids playing there. It's an unusual playground, with few structures, which is popular in Europe.
Need to talk with Debbie about the permissions on photographing kids first.
Marjorie is writing the story -- feel free to talk with her for more info. (She's in Monday through mid-day Wednesday.)

Marjorie has written a story about the work Vogel is doing, along with an engineering graduate student, Brian Thomas, about building a model of groundwater pathways in Boston.
Many buildings in Boston still have wooden pilings, which must be surrounded by groundwater, or else they rot. Vogel is examining efforts by a city agency to maintain groundwater around these pilings, to keep the buildings structurally sound.
Please talk with Taylor or Marjorie about this. Marjorie was going to be in touch with Vogel to see if he had suggestions about where to shoot this. Might just be here on campus, but might not. We might have flexibility on the pub date on this, and thus when the photo can be shot.
